Research Paper Analysis of SCR properties of metal oxide catalysts enhanced by non-thermal plasma - Promoting effect of NH3 Lin Zhu Writing – original draft Visualization Methodology Conceptualization a Zheng Zhang Supervision Resources Investigation a Xianchun Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, University of Science and Technology Liaoning, Anshan 114051, China School of Chemical Engineering University of Science and Technology Liaoning Anshan 114051 China aSchool of Chemical Engineering, University of Science and Technology Liaoning, Anshan 114051, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Traditional methods of preparing catalysts suffer from suboptimal selectivity and activity. Consequently, this study investigated the modification of iron–cerium (Fe–Ce) oxide catalysts through a non-thermal plasma technique to enhance their reaction activity. Ammonia (NH3), utilized as the reaction atmosphere during plasma treatment, plays a crucial role in enhancing denitration performance. Among them, the catalyst displays the best low-temperature SCR activity in 40 % NH3/N2 atmosphere. The initial NO conversion rate of NH3-SCR of Fe/Al2O3 catalyst at 330 °C can reach 95.3 % when the NO input was 1000ppm. The characterization results indicated that the addition of NH3 transformed the active components of the catalyst from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and Fe4 N, and increased the nitrogen content in the catalyst, thus enhancing the synergistic effect and redox capacity of the catalysts, which was conducive to the adsorption and activation of the reactants. Additionally, the dispersion of catalyst and the interaction strength between active component and support were enhanced. In addition, the sulfur resistance of the catalyst doped with Ce was significantly improved. This study presented catalysts modified using a non-thermal plasma technique, effectively enhancing catalyst dispersion and increase the content of N, providing new insights for advanced catalyst modification. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Plasma modification Sulfur resistance Ce doping NOx activity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) produced during the combustion of fossil fuels pose a serious threat to the environment and human health. Current efforts to mitigate these emissions primarily focus on two reduction methods: controlling the NOx production process [1–3] and managing emissions post-generation. Selective non-catalytic reduction (SNCR) and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) techniques represent mainstream methods for NOx removal [4–7]. The efficacy of SCR in denitrification crucially depends on catalyst selectivity and activity, achieving efficient denitrification reaction [8–13]. The denitration effect of SCR depends critically on the selectivity and activity of the catalyst to achieve an efficient denitration reaction. Therefore, the research and development of SCR catalysts with low temperature application, high catalytic activity, low cost and environmental friendliness have important research value and application significance [14–16]. Conventional preparation techniques such as impregnation, co-precipitation, and calcination, frequently produce catalysts with limited operational temperature ranges and compromised denitrification efficiency, resulting in suboptimal results for both denitrification and desulfurization. Therefore, there is a pressing need to develop catalysts with enhanced performance and stability. Non-thermal plasma (NTP) technique operates on the principle of high-voltage electric fields inducing ionization of gas molecules [17–19]. Plasmas provide an alternative to catalysts in the design and modification of oxidation, reduction, etching, coating and doping [20]. Furthermore, when applied to catalysts, NTP can modify surface properties, generate functional groups, form doping, and introduce defects, thereby enhancing catalytic activity [17]. Additionally, NTP facilitates the dissociation of metal salts into metal oxides, thereby regulating the distribution and aggregation of metal atoms [21–23]. For instance, Wang et al. [24]. demonstrated that plasma modification of Pt/CeO2 catalysts altered surface roughness and significantly enhanced toluene oxidation. Similarly, Liu et al. [25] observed enhanced activity and stability in ZSM catalysts following plasma treatment pre- and post-calcination. Notably, NTP operates at temperatures of < 200 °C, thereby preventing the sintering of active components [26–28]. Compared with precious metal catalysts, metal oxide-type catalysts generally have higher stability and durability, and lower cost. Metal oxide catalysts can be divided into integral catalysts and supported catalysts according to the existence form of active centers, among which supported catalysts often show higher catalytic efficiency [29–31]. MnOx, V2O5, CuO, FeOx and other catalysts are commonly used as active components of the catalyst, showing higher NH3-SCR activity at low temperatures [32]. SiO2, Al2O3, molecular sieve and other materials with rich surface acid sites and large specific surface area are commonly used as catalyst carriers. Shelfer et al. [33] showed that when transition metal oxides catalyzed CO reduction of NO reaction, the catalytic reduction effect of NO showed the following relationship: Fe2O3 > CuO > Cr2O3 > NiO > Co3O4 > MnO > V2O5. In recent years, the research progress of composite metal oxide catalysts has been made. Through the regulation of the composite metal catalyst can effectively improve the selectivity of the catalyst, enhance the resistance and life of the catalyst. This study employed alumina as a carrier and introduced a plasma technique to prepare Fe–Ce oxide denitrification catalysts. It investigated the effect of different plasma discharge atmospheres (N2, Ar, 40 % NH3/N2, and 40 % NH3/Ar) and NH3 concentrations (10 % NH3/N2, 40 % NH3/N2 and 70 % NH3/N2) on catalysts, discussing the influence of Ce doping on the catalytic activity, stability, and sulfur resistance. The principle novelty of this work lies in the study of the structure change of Fe-Ce oxide catalyst by plasma and its application in the field of denitrification. To promote plasma technology to practical application in the denitration catalyst modification provides theoretical basis and technical support. 2 Methods 2.1 Preparation of CexFe/Al2O3 catalyst Fig. 1 (a) shows the catalyst preparation device diagram. Initially, a specific amount of Fe(NO3)3•9H2O and Ce (NO3)3•6H2O were dissolved into deionized water to a precursor solution. Activated alumina balls were added to the precursor solution to form a suspension. After ultrasonic vibration at 55 °C for 200 min, the suspension was dried in a 105 °C air drying oven for 480 min. The dried sample was subsequently placed in a quartz tube and heated from room temperature to 350 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min under N2 protection, resulting in the catalyst undergoing calcination pretreatment. To obtain the plasma-modified catalyst (recorded as CexFe/Al2O3, Fig. 1(b)), 2 g of calcined pretreated catalyst was subjected to ionization at 240 V for 120 min in an ionization generator. The loading amount of the active component metal Fe in the catalyst remained constant at 5 %, where x represents the ratio of Ce to Fe loading. 2.2 Catalyst activity testing method The activity testing device of the CexFe/Al2O3 catalyst for catalytic reduction of NO was evaluated using the experimental setup depicted in Fig. 2 , which was conducted in a fixed bed quartz reactor with a diameter of 20 mm. A total gas flow rate of 1355 mL/min, comprising CNO = 1000 ppm, CNH3 = 1000 ppm, CO2 = 5 % (when added), and CSO2 = 100 ppm (when added), was utilized. The catalyst activity was tested in a simulated flue gas environment with N2 as the carrier gas at an airspeed of 12,000 h-1. The concentration of NO in the exhaust gas was monitored using a flue gas analyzer to assess catalyst activity. In this experiment, the NO concentration detected in the outlet exhaust gas was used to evaluate the activity of the catalyst. The calculation formula is: (1) X N O = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % In the formula, [NO]in represents the inlet NO concentration, and [NO]out represents the outlet NO concentration, in ppm. 2.3 Characterization methods of catalysts Use an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D8 ADVANCE, Bruker, Germany) to detect the active components and dispersion of the catalyst. The alumina material exhibits a greater number of XRD peaks and more pronounced peak intensities, which can lead to analytical errors. In contrast, the XRD pattern of activated carbon displays only a broad peak that does not interfere with the peak results. Consequently, all catalysts utilized in the XRD tests presented in this paper are based on activated carbon as the support material, while maintaining consistent preparation conditions solely for the purpose of XRD analysis. The activated carbon was acquired from Shanxi Xinhua in China. The specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of the catalyst were determined using a fully automatic specific surface area analyzer (Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET), Nova 200e, manufactured by Conta, USA). The morphology of metal oxides on the surface and within the pores of the catalyst was observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS Gemini 3000, Zeiss, German). Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Thermal ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) was employed to examine the elemental valence and content of active components in the catalysts, Utilizing an Al target K α source with a working voltage of 12 kV and current of 5 mA. The electrochemical shifts of different elements were verified using C 1 s with a binding energy of 284.6 eV as the standard substance, and XPS spectra were obtained. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance analysis of the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst treated with plasma 3.1.1 Effects of different discharge atmospheres on Fe/Al2O3 catalysts Fig. 3 shows the NH3-SCR activity test results of catalysts modified under different plasma discharge atmospheres. Initially, the catalyst without plasma treatment exhibited a stable NO conversion rate of 76.0 % over 130 min. Plasma treatment in N2 and Ar atmospheres marginally enhanced this rate to 76.4 % and 76.1 %, respectively. Subsequently, plasma treatment in 40 % NH3/N2 and 40 % NH3/Ar atmospheres significantly increased the initial NO conversion rate to 95.3 % and 95.1 %, respectively. However, as the reaction progressed, the NO conversion rate gradually decreased to 76.8 % and 76.4 %, and remained stable. Thus, NH3 played a crucial role in the plasma modification process. To further investigate the effect of NH3 on the active components of catalysts during plasma modification, XRD characterization analysis was conducted (Fig. 4 a). The catalyst treated without plasma exhibited diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 at 2θ = 35.64°[34]. The high-energy electrons generated in the plasma under N2 and Ar atmospheres exhibited no significant effect on the Fe2O3 reduction. The active components and NO conversion rate of the catalyst correlated with those without plasma treatment. After plasma treatment in 40 % NH3/N2 and 40 % NH3/Ar atmospheres, the catalyst exhibited diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 at 2θ = 35.24°, 2θ = 56.63°, and 2θ = 62.17°, indicating a reduction from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Concurrently, in the XRD pattern of the catalyst processed under a 40 % NH3/N2 plasma environment, a diffraction peak attributed to the Fe3O4 was observed at 2θ = 29.92°[35]. Notably, the presence of NH3 facilitated this reduction, indicating its dominant role in transforming Fe2O3 into Fe3O4 through plasma ionization. Similarly, an inconspicuous Fe4 N diffraction peak appears at 2θ=41.1°[36]. The analysis shows that the diffraction peak of Fe4 N is inconspicuous due to the strong (100) crystal plane of activated carbon at the diffraction peak 2θ=42° Fig. 4(b) showed the XPS diagram of the catalyst before and after NH3/N2 plasma treatment, the catalyst treated with NH3/N2 plasma treatment showed an obvious peak value at 397 eV, this indicates that metal nitride was formed in the catalyst after the NH3/N2 plasma treatment. Table 1 shows the XPS element content of the catalyst before and after the 40 %NH3/N2 plasma modification, and the element of N increased after the 40 %NH3/N2 modification, corresponding to the appearance of Fe4 N diffraction peak in XRD and the change of N spectra in XPS. Nitrogen doping significantly promoted the formation of oxygen cavities on the catalyst surface, which in turn improved the denitrification activity of the catalyst [37]. Figure S1 (a) displays the N2 adsorption–desorption curves of the Fe/Al2O3 catalysts. According to the classification by IUPAC [34], the adsorption–desorption curves of the Fe/Al2O3 catalysts, under various atmospheres as well as pre-and post-plasma treatment, were all classified as type IV curves, exhibiting H3 hysteresis loops. Under different plasma discharge atmospheres, the catalysts have the same type of adsorption isotherms, and all have rich and irregular mesoporous structures. Figure S1 (b) depicts the pore size distribution of Fe/Al2O3 catalysts pre- and post-plasma treatment in various atmospheres. The graph illustrates that the peak positions of the pore size distribution for Fe/Al2O3 catalysts treated with plasma in different atmospheres remain unchanged. However, the peak areas for the pore size distribution of catalysts treated with plasma in N2 and Ar atmospheres, without prior plasma treatment, significantly exceeded those in the 40 % NH3/N2 and 40 % NH3/Ar atmospheres. This indicated a reduction in the number of mesopores in the catalyst under NH3 plasma discharge conditions, owing to the Fe3O4 formation. Table S1 presents the specific surface area and pore characteristics of catalysts subjected to plasma treatment under various discharge atmospheres. Under N2 and Ar atmosphere, the plasma treatment of specific surface area and total pore volume of catalysts with untreated catalyst. This similarity was attributable to the unchanged active component of Fe2O3 in catalysts treated under N2 and Ar atmospheres, thereby resulting in comparable specific surface areas and pore volumes. However, for catalysts treated with plasma in 40 %NH3/N2 and 40 %NH3/Ar atmospheres, NH3 addition in the reduction reaction transformed the active component into Fe3O4. This magnetic substance tended to spontaneously aggregate, leading to a reduction in both the specific surface area and total pore volume [38]. The BET characterization findings correlated with the activity tests of the catalyst and XRD results. To investigate the effect of plasma discharge atmosphere on the morphology of catalysts, SEM characterization was conducted on catalysts without plasma treatment and those modified through plasma treatment under different discharge atmospheres in Fig 5 . Fig. 5(a) shows the SEM image of the catalyst without plasma treatment. It was observed that the catalyst exhibited a clear and complete pore structure, and the active components were relatively dispersed. Therefore, the catalyst also exhibited the largest specific surface area and pore volume. The SEM images in Figs. 5(b) and (c) show the surface morphology of the catalyst after plasma treatment in Ar and N2 atmospheres, respectively. The pore structure characteristics corresponded to those of the catalyst without plasma treatment, and the dispersion of active components was relatively high. The SEM images in Figs. 5(d) and 5 (e) depict the morphology of the catalyst following plasma treatment in atmospheres of 40 % NH3/Ar and 40 % NH3/N2, respectively. The presence of NH3 led to the reduction of active components on the catalyst to Fe3O4, accompanied by the onset of agglomeration. The substantial Fe3O4 obstructed catalyst pores, thereby reducing the surface area of the catalyst and pore volume. 3.1.2 Effect of NH3/N2 concentration on Fe/Al2O3 catalyst Fig. 6 illustrates the activity test diagram of the catalyst following plasma modification at varying concentrations of NH3. During the plasma treatment process, the initial NO conversion rate for the catalyst modified with 10 % NH3/N2 was recorded at 94.1 %, and the catalyst maintained its initial NO conversion rate for a duration of 15 min before deactivation commenced. After 95 min of reaction, the NO conversion rate decreased to 74.3 % and stabilized thereafter. The activity of the catalyst modified under plasma treatment in a 40 % NH3/N2 atmosphere exhibited a slight enhancement compared to that modified in a 10 % NH3/N2 environment. The initial conversion rate of NO was 95.3 %, but the lifetime of the catalyst was significantly enhanced. Notably, the initial conversion rate of NO could be maintained for 50 min before deactivation. Conversely, when the catalyst was treated by plasma in 70 %NH3/N2 atmosphere, the initial conversion of NO and the catalyst lifetime were lower than those prepared in the other two atmospheres. Under 70 % NH3 / N2 atmosphere catalysts modified by plasma treatment NO initial conversion rate was 88.7 %, the deactivation rate faster, catalyst in 55 min after the NO conversion rate dropped to 74.6 %. Fig. 7 (a) illustrates the XRD characterization of catalysts synthesized at different NH3 concentrations. The plasma treated catalyst in N2 atmosphere exhibits only the characteristic peak of Fe2O3 at 2θ=35.64° For catalysts prepared under 10 %NH3/N2, 40 %NH3/N2, and 70 %NH3/N2 atmospheres, the characteristic peaks of Fe3O4 were observed at 2θ=35.24°, 56.63°, and 62.17°, respectively, while the characteristic peaks corresponding to Fe2O3 disappeared. Notably, Fe2O3 can also be reduced to Fe3O4 in a 10 %NH3/N2 environment. As NH3 concentration increases during reduction, the characteristic peak of Fe3O4 sharpens, indicating that the crystallinity of Fe3O4 increased and the dispersion decreased. The agglomeration of active components reduced the exposure area of active sites and inhibited the catalytic activity of the catalyst.. The active component Fe3O4 demonstrates superior reactivity compared to Fe2O3. Consequently, although the dispersibility of Fe3O4 was reduced, the 40 %NH3/N2 catalyst still has a high denitrification activity. Figure S2 (a) illustrates the adsorption and desorption curves of catalysts synthesized under different NH3 concentrations during the plasma treatment process. The results indicate that the catalysts treated with plasma at three different NH3 concentrations exhibit type IV isotherms accompanied by H3 hysteresis loops, indicating that the catalysts modified under three different NH3 atmospheric concentrations have mesoporous structures, mesoporous pores were abundant and irregular. Figure S2 (b) presents the pore size distribution of the catalyst prepared via plasma treatment at different NH3 concentrations. Notably, both the peak value and area for the catalyst synthesized at a 40 % NH3 concentration surpassed those of catalysts produced at 10 % and 70 % NH3 atmospheres. The results that the catalyst prepared at 40 % NH3 concentration exhibits superior mesoporosity, which enhances the dispersion of active components within the catalyst, thereby facilitating improved denitrification activity. Table S2 shows the specific surface area and pore size parameters of the catalyst prepared by plasma treatment at different NH3 concentrations. Differing NH3 levels did not significantly influence pore size distribution, all three catalysts maintained an average pore size of approximately 4.54 nm. However, as NH3 concentration increased during plasma treatment, the specific surface area and total pore volume of the catalyst were reduced to varying degrees, due to the increase of NH3 concentration in the plasma treatment process was conducive to the reduction reaction of active components. A substantial amount of Fe3O4 was generated during the plasma treatment process, which gradually obstructed the surface and pore channels of the catalyst, resulting in the decrease of the specific surface area and total pore volume of the catalyst. Particularly, the specific surface area of the catalyst treated with plasma at 70 %NH3 concentration decreased, indicating that agglomeration of Fe3O4 occurred in the catalyst pore channel, which due to the fact that high concentration of NH3 would speed up the reduction reaction rate of Fe3O4. Fe3O4 generated in large quantities and rapidly in the pore channel would also block the pore structure of the catalyst, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreases. The higher NH3 concentration in the plasma treatment process accelerates the reduction of Fe3O4 and decreases the dispersion of the active component Fe3O4. Fig. 8 presents SEM images depicting catalysts modified by plasma across different NH3 concentrations. The pore structure of the catalyst modified by plasma at the concentration of 10 %NH3 was clear in Fig 8(a), minimal amounts of uniformly dispersed Fe3O4 showed no significant agglomeration, consistent with the BET results. Fig. 8(b) displays the SEM image for catalysts subjected to plasma treatment at a concentration of 40 %NH3, the inner surface of the pore was covered with flocculent Fe3O4. Conversely, as illustrated in Fig. 8(c), substantial blockage within pores became apparent for catalysts treated under conditions involving a concentration level reaching up to 70 %NH3. Due to the high concentration of NH3 in the plasma speeds up the reduction reaction rate and generates a large amount of Fe3O4, which simultaneously gathers with each other under the action of magnetic force. The specific surface area of the catalyst decreases, resulting in low denitrification efficiency and reduced stability. 3.2 Performance analysis of the Ce-Fe/Al2O3 catalyst treated with plasma Fig. 9 (a) shows the NH3-SCR activity test results of the CexFe/Al2O3 catalyst at different reaction temperatures. The loading of Ce enhanced the low-temperature denitrification activity of the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst and facilitated the working window of NH3-SCR to shift toward the low-temperature direction. For the CexFe/Al2O3 catalyst, when x (the ratio of Ce to Fe loading) was > 0.2, the catalyst exhibited excellent low-temperature denitrification activity, and the initial NO conversion rate exceeded 88.2 % at 210 °C. At 240 °C, the initial NO conversion rate was > 93.4 %. Within the temperature range of 270 °C–330 °C, the NO conversion rate exceeded 96.2 % and did not change significantly with increasing temperature. The reason for the significantly poor low-temperature activity of the Ce0.2Fe/Al2O3 catalyst was attributable to the lower Ce doping amount and fewer active centers, resulting in lower low-temperature denitrification performance compared with other Ce-loaded catalysts. When the ratio of Ce to Fe loading was 1.0, the NO conversion rate of the catalyst was significantly low within the temperature range of 150 °C–180 °C. This was attributed to the high Ce loading, which subsequently decreased the specific surface area of the Ce1.0Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. In the plasma treatment process, the active components aggregated, leading to a reduction in the exposed active sites of the catalyst, thereby reducing the low-temperature denitrification activity of the catalyst. The denitrification performance of the catalyst initially increased and then decreased with increasing Ce loading. Due to the strong interaction between Ce and Fe, Fe-O-Ce bond was formed after plasma modification, and Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst shows excellent denitrification performance in the range of 150 °C to 330 °C. Fig. 9(b) shows the sulfur resistance test of the CexFe/Al2O3 catalyst. After the reaction stabilized, 100 ppm of SO2 was introduced. The denitrification activity and sulfur resistance of the Ce-doped catalyst were significantly enhanced compared with the undoped catalyst. The initial NO conversion rate of the Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst was 97.8 %, indicating an increase of 2.7 % over the undoped Ce-Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. The addition of a substantial amount of Ce enhanced the denitrification performance of the catalyst at low temperatures. This enhancement was attributable to the inherent strong redox capability of Ce. Additionally, during the plasma modification process, Fe-O-Ce bonds were formed between the metal ions and the carrier, leading to increased dispersion and enhanced denitrification activity of the catalyst. Upon introducing 100 ppm of SO2, the NO conversion rate of the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst without Ce doping rapidly declined from 95.3 % to 58.9 % and further decreased to 54.1 % within 60 min. This decline was attributable to the formation of ferrous sulfate precipitate through the reaction between SO2 and Fe, resulting in decreased catalytic performance. Catalysts doped with various molar ratios of Ce/Fe exhibited significantly enhanced sulfur resistance, with the NO conversion rate stabilizing within 60 min. The enhanced sulfur resistance stemmed from SO2 preferentially reacting with Ce to form cerium sulfate, thereby preventing catalyst poisoning and deactivation due to the interaction between SO2 and Fe. After cutting the introduction of SO2, the NO conversion rate of the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst without Ce doping gradually recovered to 58.3 %. The thermal decomposition attributed to the specific ammonium sulfate precipitation, indicating more active sites for the adsorption of NH3 and NO, thus increasing the conversion rate of NO. After cutting SO2, the NO conversion rate of the Ce0.2Fe/Al2O3 catalyst reverted to 84.1 %. However, other catalysts returned to their initial NO conversion rates before SO2 exposure, the failure of the Ce0.2Fe/Al2O3 catalyst to return to its initial NO conversion rate was attributable to the low Ce loading, which prevented the complete conversion of SO2 into cerium sulfate. Portions of SO2 reacted with Fe3O4 to form ferrous sulfate, thereby reducing the activity of the catalyst active sites and consequently lowering its NO conversion efficiency. The Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest denitrification activity and sulfur resistance stability. Upon exposure to 100 ppm SO2, the NO conversion rate dropped from 97.8 % to 93.4 %. After SO2 was stopped, the NO conversion rate of the Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst recovered from 93.4 % to 96.3 %, which was slightly below the initial rate. Fig. 10 shows the reusability of Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. After 5 cycles of use, Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst still maintains more than 95 % denitrification performance. Therefore, Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst has good catalytic stability. Fig. 11 depicts the Fe 2p and Ce 3d XPS spectra for the Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst pre and post-sulfur resistance test. Figs. 11(a) and (b) show the Fe 2p XPS spectra for the pre- and post-sulfur resistance-tested catalysts, respectively. Both catalysts exhibited significant peaks at 711.1 eV and 724.4 eV, which was attributable to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively. Furthermore, following peak fitting, binding energies of 709.7 eV and 723.9 eV represent characteristic peaks for Fe2+, while peaks at 710.9 eV, 712.2 eV, 725.9 eV, and 733.8 eV, correspond to Fe3+. The satellite peaks for Fe were located at binding energies of 714.0 eV and 718.9 eV The ratio of Fe2+ to (Fe2+ + Fe3+) for the fresh catalyst was 53.63 %, which was similar to the Fe2+ proportion (49.90 %) of the catalyst after the sulfur resistance test. This indicated that the valence state of the Fe element in the catalyst remained unchanged for the pre-and post-sulfur resistance tests. Figs. 11(c) and (d) show the Ce 3d XPS spectra for the fresh and sulfur-resistant catalysts. The characteristic peaks at binding energies of 885.8 eV and 899.2 eV correspond to Ce3+, while the peaks at 881.9 eV, 903.8 eV, and 924.4 eV were characteristics of Ce4+. The Ce3+/(Ce4++Ce3+) value of the fresh catalyst was 56.90 %. However, given the sulfur resistance test, the proportion of Ce3+ in the catalyst significantly increased to 67.01 %, indicating that the Ce in the catalyst transformed from CeO2 to Ce2(SO4)3. Meanwhile, the valence state of the Fe in the catalyst remained unchanged for the pre-post-sulfur resistance test, indicating that Ce preferentially combines with SO2 to form cerium sulfate, thereby protecting the active components of the catalyst. Figure S3 (a) displays the N2 adsorption–desorption curves for the catalysts pre- and post- sulfur resistance test. The results reveals that the N2 adsorption-desorption curves of fresh Fe/Al2O3 and Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalysts and the N2 adsorption-desorption curves after sulfur resistance test have similar structural characteristics, and both belong to type IV curves with H3 hysteresis loops. The pore structure in both the fresh and post-sulfur resistance-tested catalysts predominantly features irregularly shaped and hollow pores. Figure S3 (b) shows the pore size distribution for the fresh Fe/Al2O3, Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3, and the post-sulfur resistance tests. As depicted, the positions of the peaks in the pore size distribution remained unchanged, indicating that SO2 did not impact the pore size distribution of the catalyst. However, the peak areas of both catalysts after the sulfur resistance test were significantly smaller compared with the fresh catalysts, indicating a reduction in the number of mesopores in the catalysts post-test. Table S3 presents the specific surface area and pore structure parameters of the catalysts pre- and post-sulfur resistance test. The fresh Fe/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest specific surface area and total pore volume. Given the sulfur resistance test, the specific surface area and total pore volume of Fe/Al2O3 catalyst were significantly lower than that of fresh Fe/Al2O3 catalyst. This was attributable to the formation of ammonium sulfate precipitates, resulting from the combination of NH3 and SO2, covering the catalyst surface, thereby leading to pore blockage. Conversely, the Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a minor decline in specific surface area compared with the fresh Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3, indicating that the addition of Ce effectively promoted the decomposition of ammonium sulfate precipitation and reduced the specific surface area. Meanwhile, the sulfur resistance of cerium in the catalyst was enhanced. Fig. 12 depicts the SEM of the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst following the sulfur resistance test before and after loading Ce. Fig. 12(a) illustrates that the introduction of SO2 leads to the formation of a conspicuous layer of precipitate on the surface of the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst, concurrently with a marked decrease in the porosity. The reaction of SO2 and NH3 leads to the formation of precipitation of ammonium sulfate and ammonium bisulfate on the catalyst surface, which covers and partially blocks the pore structure, inhibits the contact between the active site of the catalyst and the gaseous reaction molecules, and ultimately leads to the catalyst deactivation. Fig. 12(b) shows the SEM image of the Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst after SO2 was added, A large number of spherical clumps were observed on the surface of the catalyst, which may be precipitated by the interaction between CeO2 and SO2. However, fresh Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst did not show significant star clusters in Fig. 12(c). In conclusion, the addition of cerium not only accelerates the decomposition of sulfate, but also provides protection for the active Fe3O4 component of the catalyst. Conclusively, the inadequate sulfur resistance of Fe/Al2O3 catalysts primarily arises from the formation of ammonium sulfate precipitates resulting from the interaction between SO2 and NH3, which disrupted the catalyst pores and covered active sites, thereby impeding the adsorption of NH3 and NO, ultimately leading to catalyst deactivation. Notably, the enhancement in the sulfur resistance of the Ce0.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst was attributable to Ce addition, which enhances the decomposition rate of ammonium sulfate precipitates while preferentially binding with SO2 to form more stable cerium sulfate precipitates that protect active sites. thereby protecting the active sites. Consequently, the Fe/Al2O3 catalyst with Ce loading exhibited superior denitrification activity and enhanced sulfur resistance stability. 3.3 Mechanism analysis of the Ce-Fe/Al2O3 reaction system The low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction initiates with NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface, which was followed by two distinct reaction pathways. At lower temperatures, the L–H mechanism (with an activation energy of 25.1 kJ/mol) was more likely to occur compared with the E–R mechanism (activation energy of 56.4 kJ/mol). Wang et al. [39] also observed that both mechanisms coexisted in Fe-based catalysts for NH3-SCR, with the L–H mechanism predominating at low temperatures. The corresponding reaction equations are as follows: (2) O2→2(O) (3) NH3+(O)→NH2+OH (4) NH2+NO→NH2NO→N2+H2O (5) NO+1/2O2→NO2 (6) OH+NO2→(O)+HNO2 (7) NH3+NO2→N2+H2O+OH (8) NH3+HNO2→NH4NO2→N2+H2O (9) 2OH→H2O+(O) (10) 2Fe3O4+(O)→3Fe2O3 (11) Ce2O3+(O)→2CeO2 (12) O2+2CeO2+3SO2→Ce2(SO4)3 Initially, gaseous NH3 molecules were adsorbed onto acidic sites of the Fe3O4. Subsequently, O2 molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface underwent cleavage of the O–O bond due to the action of Fe3O4, generating active oxygen species (O) (Eq. (2)). The adsorbed NH3 underwent dehydrogenation reaction with the active oxygen species (O), resulting in the formation of amide radicals (NH2 -) (Eq. (3)). Furthermore, NH2 - reacted with gaseous NO to form nitrosamines (NH2NO), which subsequently decomposed into N2 and H2O (Eq. (4)), corresponding to the E–R mechanism [40]. On the Fe3O4 catalyst, NO was also adsorbed and oxidized to form NO2 (Eq. (5)) and nitrite (HNO2) (Eq. (6)). Additionally, NH3 reacted with NO2 (Eq. (7)), and NH3 reacted with HNO2 to form ammonium nitrite (NH4NO2), which decomposed into N2 and H2O (Eq. (8)), corresponding to the L–H mechanism [41]. The active components Fe3O4/Ce2O3 in the catalyst offered acidic adsorption sites for NH3 and NO in the catalytic reactions in Fig. 13 . Concurrently, the adsorbed O2 molecules were cleaved, generating active oxygen (O), with a substantial amount of it participating in reactions on the surface of the catalyst. The active component Fe3O4 of the catalyst contained two valence states of Fe ions, with electrons transferring between Fe3+ and Fe2+ throughout the reaction. However, due to the inherent instability of Fe2+, it was readily oxidized by oxygen to Fe3+ (Eq. (10)) [42]. Subsequently, Ce3+ was readily oxidized by oxygen to Ce4+ (Eq. (11)), resulting in the gradual oxidation of Fe3O4/Ce2O3 to Fe2O3/CeO2 as the reaction progressed. This alteration in the active component led to a decline in the activity of the catalyst, eventually leading to its deactivation. Analysis of Ce sulfur resistance indicated that SO2 on the surface of Ce was initially oxidized to SO3, which was followed by the formation of surface cerium sulfate, thereby representing a sulfation process on CeO2 (Eq. (12)). 4 Conclusion With the continuous development of catalytic processes in chemistry, biology, organic synthesis, energy production and other fields, catalyst modification technology has attracted wide attention. Most of the current catalyst modification methods are time-consuming, complex and use polluting chemical reagents to regulate the structural properties of catalysts. The plasma forms a highly active mixture through gas ionization, which changes the physical structure and chemical properties of the catalyst. However, at present the research in this aspect is less. In this study, plasma technology was used to modify the catalyst. In the NH3 N2 modified atmosphere, the denitrification activity of the catalyst was the best. When the amount of NO input was 1000 ppm, the initial NO conversion rate of NH3-SCR of Fe/Al2O3 catalyst at 330 °C could reach 95.3 %.NH3 converts Fe2O3 into more active Fe3O4 rather than high-energy particles, thereby improving the reduction efficiency of NO. It is worth noting that the addition of NH3 can increase the nitrogen content inside the catalyst, generate more acid and oxygen vacancies on its surface, and promote the adsorption and activation of the reactants. However, with the increase of NH3 concentration, the reduction rate of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 was accelerated, and the active groups were slightly agglomerated. At the same time, the dispersion of catalyst was enhanced by plasma treatment. In addition, due to the synergistic effect between metals, Fe and Ce co-supported catalysts exhibit the best nitrogen removal activity and sulfur resistance stability, with an optimal Ce load of 0.6 %.At 330 °C, the initial NO conversion can reach 97.8 %. Ce doping not only promoted the decomposition of ammonium sulfate precipitation, but also preferentially combined with SO2, thus enhancing the sulfur resistance of the catalyst. This lays a foundation for the subsequent development and application of plasma modified metal oxide catalysts. The main purpose of this study is to promote the application of plasma treatment catalyst in the field of denitrification. However, the plasma modification process is very complex, including physical changes on the catalyst surface, changes in the heat generated during the modification, and changes in the control structure on the material surface (micron (particle), nano, molecular and even atomic scales). Unfortunately, this study lacks research on the recyclability and long-term stability of catalysts. The performance of these catalysts should be further studied in the future to provide more reference value for the application of plasma modified catalysis in other fields. coredata.dc:description: Traditional methods of preparing catalysts suffer from suboptimal selectivity and activity. Consequently, this study investigated the modification of iron–cerium (Fe–Ce) oxide catalysts through a non-thermal plasma technique to enhance their reaction activity. Ammonia (NH3), utilized as the reaction atmosphere during plasma treatment, plays a crucial role in enhancing denitration performance. Among them, the catalyst displays the best low-temperature SCR activity in 40 % NH3/N2 atmosphere. The initial NO conversion rate of NH3-SCR of Fe/Al2O3 catalyst at 330 °C can reach 95.3 % when the NO input was 1000ppm. The characterization results indicated that the addition of NH3 transformed the active components of the catalyst from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and Fe4 N, and increased the nitrogen content in the catalyst, thus enhancing the synergistic effect and redox capacity of the catalysts, which was conducive to the adsorption and activation of the reactants. Additionally, the dispersion of catalyst and the interaction strength between active component and support were enhanced. In addition, the sulfur resistance of the catalyst doped with Ce was significantly improved. This study presented catalysts modified using a non-thermal plasma technique, effectively enhancing catalyst dispersion and increase the content of N, providing new insights for advanced catalyst modification.
